comments.author: Tofu Hunter
comments.content: This reminds me of something that I discovered recently about corn vs flour tortillas: Store bought flour tortillas tend to be loaded with salt, while store bought corn tortillas generally have little to no salt in them, yet corn tortillas still taste plenty good. I realized this while coming up with things to eat for a relative who is salt sensitive, and was shocked to see how much salt it is possible to consume unwittingly in just the flour tortillas in a quesadilla.

comments.author: fanny
comments.content:
Michael, how come I always find myself starving each time I visit your blog.

I mean, all your recipes; they just look like what I would cook if pastry didn't take all my time.

Gorgeous!

xx fanny

comments.author: Rosa
comments.content:
Those Quesadillas look fantastic! Really scrumptious! Thanks for the tip!

Cheers,

Rosa

comments.author: Fairly Odd Tofu Mom
comments.content:
I just discovered the joys of corn tortilla quesadillas. SO much better than flour! Wow, who knew?

Thanks for the tip about getting them crispy, we've been doing (vegan) pesto quesadillas with marinara. Sort-of a Mex-Italian "fusion" thing, right? SOOOOOO good!!

Always love your posts as usual!

comments.author: Deborah
comments.content: I've actually never made a quesadilla with corn tortillas, but I'm going to be trying one now!

comments.author: Dawn
comments.content: Mmm... now you've inspired me to go make some quesadillas!  Especially with that photo.  And I love the idea of figs inside.

comments.author: Nate
comments.content: waiting for your crispy flour tortillas post.  We made our own whole wheat tortillas the other week and they were nice and soft.  But crispy sounds like another texture that I'd enjoy.

comments.author: [eatingclub] vancouver || js
comments.content:
These look amazing!

I love corn tortillas (over flour tortillas), but the trouble is they're harder to find than their flour brethren. I might have to go find some because I want these!

comments.author: Hillary
comments.content: I love quesadillas! I was thinking about making some grilled peach quesadillas. Thanks for reminding me I wanted to do that :)

comments.author: Madeline
comments.content: Great tip! I've never thought of using corn tortillas. I can't wait to try this recipe. And I need to get some of that onion and garlic jam.

comments.author: Lore
comments.content: I simply adore quesadillas! Thanks so much for the tip. They look yummy

comments.author: Kevin
comments.content: Those quesadillas look good.  I usually add a touch of butter to the pan when cooking flour tortillas but they certainly don;t come out as crispy as those look!

comments.author: Kathleen
comments.content:
Hi,

I need your help!  I am flying to Sea-Tac next Thursday, and a friend is driving down from Bellingham to meet me for lunch.  Do you have any suggestions for a cheap-ish lunch for two friends who want to catch up (i.e. no quick grab & go) in the Seattle/Sea-Tac area?

Thanks!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hi Kathleen - one thought might be Cafe Flora, the place I used to work. It is vegetarian and moderately priced. It is in the city. I don't know that there is anything I can particularly recommend down by the airport. You can see all my restaurant reviews here. If you let me know more about what you like I'll be happy to offer some other ideas. Michael

comments.author: Barbara Stewart
comments.content:
Thanks Michael,
I can't wait to try this method of making quesadillas crispy - the filling may need to be different for two munchkins, but Glenn and I will definitely try this recipe.
I am intrigued by going vegetarian, although never quite get there, so I always enjoy adding to my repertoire.
Barbara

comments.author: Sue Hayes
comments.content: Sounds (and looks) great! I especially like white corn tortillas, and am going to try this with them.

comments.author: MEM
comments.content:
Ah, yis...the secret, revealed.

We make a lot of corn quesadillas here, probably too many.

I tend to use walnut oil (or butter, depending on the filling) as my brushing oil because here in Yurp it's about the same price as olive oil, and the flavor is so much more complementary to Mexican and Southwestern food.

I also dust my quesadillas with a little smoked paprika and cinnamon while they're in the pan. Smells great and adds a bit of mystery, long as you don't use too much.

comments.author: maritza
comments.content: I live in Holland, would love 2 make this quesadilla if only someone could tell me where I can buy that jam??.. :(

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: If you can't buy it, try caramelizing lots of onions and garlic, then cooking them down in simple syrup. You'd have to use it within a few days though unless you know how to make it safe for canning (not my specialty!).

comments.author: Heather
comments.content: If you want even more flavor, brush it with butter instead of oil.

comments.author: Solid
comments.content: I just recently started making my quesadillas with corn tortillas. I heat up the tortillas up in a pinch of oil much like you do with enchiladas so they get soft. then sandwich them and reheat. I use Peanut Oil, adds so much flavor to them; they're at the perfect balance between crisp and soft.
